Subject: Re: Backpropagation and NEAT

Daniel, the ability to represent patterns with CPPNs in NEAT/HyperNEAT
is i=
ndeed intended to provide a bias.  It biases the search toward
certain type=
s of solutions that would otherwise be less likely to be
reached.  Of cours=
e, as a consequence, it means that some solutions
become less likely.  Howe=
ver the bias is provided under the assumption
that the solutions to many pr=
actical problems involve some kind of
pattern or regularity.  

The idea go=
es beyond simply discovering the right pattern; it also
means preserving it=
 as it is elaborated.  For example, the encoding
may discover bilateral sym=
metry early on, and from that point onward
elaborations that are discovered=
 through mutation are also likely to
be symmetric.  So the discovery itself=
 biases the future of the search.

The main problem that is being addressed=
 is that repetition and
repetition with variation are a necessary part of n=
eural circuitry to
approach real world problems.  For example, there are mi=
llions of
receptive fields in the human eye that project back to the brain,=
 each
creating the same connectivity motif.  An algorithm that had to
disco=
ver each such motif independently would be impractical.  In fact,
most algo=
rithms in machine learning today have that very problem. In
contrast, Hyper=
NEAT can discover all of them at once, and then improve
all of them togethe=
r, by discovery the pattern first.

ken


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Dan=
iel Tuohy" <danielr2e@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Ken,
> 
> I'm curious about how th=
e idea of identifying patterns in NEAT is
related to
> inductive bias.  Are=
 identified patterns used to impose a bias by
which to
> carve up the decis=
ion space, or merely to provide heuristic direction to
> NEAT on how the sp=
ace can be usefully partitioned?
> 
> Thanks,
> Daniel

 2008 at 7:38 PM, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>
> wrote:

ybe you can provide an example of "non-linear inequality
> > feasibility co=
nstraints" that "utterly destroy" patterns and
> > regularities?

think most people would agree that many practical problems involve
> > some=
 kind of pattern. The human brain itself is filled with
> > spectacular exa=
mples of neural patterns, both spatially and
> > temporally. Is the human b=
rain "utterly destroyed" by "non-linear
> > inequality feasibility constrai=
nts?"
> >
> > I get your broader point, though. You're saying that I'm gett=
ing a
> > distorted perspective because I'm conentrating on patterns when
>=
 > there are other factors in the world than just patterns. Yet we
> > cann=
ot expect every new algorithm to simultaneously address every

 faced by man. Any researcher who would try to do that

anywhere. With HyperNEAT we have taken a step in a
> > promising direction;=
 no more, no less. If you feel it should be

nt additional particular concerns that
> > you have (which for me are still=
 fuzzy), I encourage you to extend
> > it in that direction.
> >
> > I thin=
k your quote from Einstein is delivered in entirely the wrong
> > context. =
The problem of representation is largely ignored by the
> > machine learnin=
g community because it *is* the difficult part.
> > The "thin part of the w=
ood" is the minutia of gradient optimization,
> > which have been beaten to=
 death; yet scientists to this day still
> > focus on it intently. The reas=
on they do that is because it's the
> > easy part, not the hard part. It is=
 easy to climb a hill once you
> > see it; it is hard to move the hill itse=
lf. Representation means
> > moving the hills. I believe Einstein would hav=
e no objection to
> > rearranging the intellectual landscape.
> >
> > ken

earch. Our group has

atterns appropriate to what would otherwise appear to be

domains. The idea is to develop a theory of generic

eneration and to show that patterns are interchangeable across

=

omes

> pattern

rather

rers than

und if

EAT.

eeder. So you see,
